Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Situation2: They notice a local festival happening nearby and casually stop to observe some of the decorations and rituals.
Story: I was called urgently to the factory floor—the main production unit had been down for half an hour, and the supervisor’s voice was tight with worry. As the machine repairer, everyone expected me to diagnose the sensor errors quickly and get the line running again. I hurried past the loading dock, toolbox in hand, but the sound of drums and laughter drifted in from the street. Through the open gate, I glimpsed bright marigold garlands and the swirl of saris. Today was the local festival, and as a Hindu, I was expected to join the rituals, offer prayers, and celebrate with my community. For a moment, I paused, watching the puja in progress, feeling the pull of tradition and belonging. But behind me, the factory’s silence pressed in, a reminder of the team waiting for me to fix the problem. My heart pounded with the weight of both worlds—my duty to my work, and my devotion to my faith—each demanding my presence, each unwilling to wait.
